title: Ford offers 2 years free charging to buyers of electric cars like expected 'Mustang-inspired' SUV
text:
CLOSE

Ford said Thursday that it will offer two years of free charging-station access to buyers of its electric cars.

The automaker has arranged access to 12,000 charging stations with more than 35,000 plugs in what it's calling the FordPass Charging Network.

The deal, made with charging provider Greenlots, includes access to multiple networks of stations.

Buyers of Ford electric cars, such as the much-anticipated "Mustang-inspired" SUV to be released in 2020, will get two years of electricity for free from those stations.

The company also said it had authorized Amazon to sell installation services for home chargers.

“The fact that most of our customers will plug in at home is a key advantage to an all-electric vehicle,” Matt Stover, Ford's director of charging, energy services and business development, said in a statement. "We will deliver a charging experience that is hassle-free whether you’re at home or on-the-go.”

Electrify America, an electric car charger producer, has opened a charging station Wednesday, Jan. 16, 2019, in Paducah, Ky. The charging station is located at the side of the parking lot at the Walmart store on Hinkleville Road. (Ellen O'Nan/The Paducah Sun via AP) ORG XMIT: KYPAD400 (Photo: Ellen O'Nan, AP)

The offer includes access to charging stations installed by Electrify America, which received funding from the Volkswagen emissions scandal settlement. Electrify America said it expects to have 800 stations with 3,500 chargers in 45 states and Washington, D.C. by December 2021.
